tasks.title: Task 1: Preliminary Outline
tasks.description:
Preliminary Outline

Identify a specific topic that intersects your practice with a theoretical framework.

Submit a 400–600 word outline that includes the following headings, at a minimum:

  1. Introduction
  2. Theory
  3. Discussion
  4. Conclusion

For this task, it is best to avoid relying on LLM-generated outlines. Please write the outline yourself.

   DOWNLOAD THE PRESCRIBED READING

   DOWNLOAD THE EXAMPLE OUTLINE

tasks.title: Task 3: Essay Draft + LLM Critique + Self-Reflective Analysis
tasks.description:
Expanded Research and Reflection

Expand upon the initial outline with more detailed research and critical analysis. Students will make use of a Large Language model (LLM), such as ChatGPT, Google Bard, or Anthropic’s ClaudeAI, to provide them with structured feedback on their initial draft, accompanied by a self-reflective commentary of the feedback.

Content:

  • A 750 – 900 word expanded draft that delves deeper into the chosen topic, incorporating academic sources, media examples, and critical arguments. (GOOGLE DOC)
  • The feedback generated by the LLM model. (PDF)
  • A 300 – 400 word self-reflective analysis discussing the feedback from the LLM system. (GOOGLE DOC)

Provide each component as a separate document, in the format specified.

  TUTORIAL ON HOW TO USE THE TEMPLATE

   DOWNLOAD EXAMPLE DRAFT

tasks.title: Task 4: Essay Peer Review
tasks.description:
Peer Review Draft

Continue to refine your draft further. Then, submit your assignment for peer review on Canvas and participate in the peer review activity.

Content:

  • A 1,200 - 1,500 word expanded draft that incorporates the feedback from previous drafts

Students will be allocated 3 - 4 peers for review, using the rubric provided. Students will have 1 week to complete their peer review.

Students must write a short paragraph (50 - 75 words) of feedback for each of their allocated peers. Students who do not complete their assigned reviews will not be eligible for their own assignment mark.

USING THE FEEDBACK RUBRIC

When participating in the peer review assignment, students will use the rubric on Canvas to assign a mark to their peers' assignments.

The mark for each component is on a scale of 1 - 10. Assign marks as follows in response to each question:

1 - 2: Missing or grossly insufficient quality

3 - 4: Present but of insufficient quality

5 - 6: Sufficient quality

7 - 8: Good quality

9 - 10: Excellent quality

Students are required to provide at least 10 - 15 words of feedback per marking criteria (60 - 75 words total).

Feedback should be structured along the SPARK method:

  • Specific: Comments are linked to a discrete word, phrase, or sentence.
  • Prescriptive: Like a medical prescription that aims to solve an ailment, prescriptive feedback offers a solution or strategy to improve the work, including possible revisions or links to helpful resources or examples. 
  • Actionable: When the feedback is read, it leaves the peer knowing what steps to take for improvement.
  • Referenced: The feedback directly references the task criteria, requirements, or target skills. 
  • Kind: It’s mandatory that all comments be framed in a kind, supportive way. 

The lecturer reserves the right to override any marks should they be deemed inappropriate.

raw_canvas_data.name: Task 4: Essay Peer Review

rubric.long_description: How well does the assignment convey its ideas in a clear and concise way?
How consistently does the assignment reference its sources, both in-text and in the Reference list?
How logical is the order of paragraphs in the assignment?
How consistently does the assignment make use of academic sources such as readers, books, or journal articles?
How well does the assignment apply the chosen theory to the provided case study?

tasks.title: Task 6: Final Essay Submission
tasks.description:
Comprehensive Self-Reflexive Analysis

Present a well-researched, critically analysed, and revised paper.

Content:

  • A 1,500 - 1,800 word comprehensive paper that encapsulates all aspects of the research and analysis conducted.
  • The paper should demonstrate a deep understanding of your own work in relation to your chosen theory.
  • Your paper should be professionally written, in APA format, with a logically presented argument.
  • Integration of theory, media analysis, and critical perspectives is required to pass.

   DOWNLOAD EXAMPLE ESSAY

tasks.title: Task 1 (Part 1): CV Draft
tasks.description:
Assessment Task 1: CV Draft (Submit on Canvas)

Students should profile themselves using the following:

  1. CV (2 pages maximum)

Your CV is due by the Thursday the 27th of March, 14:00 (end of the lunch break) in week 7.

Each student is required to formulate a professional CV draft, this draft can be edited and revisited later in the year as a living document that you can use for professional purposes. During Term 1 Week 5's first session, the CV will be discussed - and students are expected to apply the advice provided during this session in order to formulate a CV that profiles the student’s aspirations, strengths and intentions. Also include basic information like your education and work experience if available. Here are some previous student examples of CVs. 

 

SUBMISSION REQUIREMENTS:

*Submit your cv of 2 pages (no more) via the Canvas assignment. Submit a clearly legible pdf file.

FILE NAME: StudentName_Surname_Student number_CV  | FORMAT: PDF ONLY, no more than 2 pages | FILE SIZE: max 15MB

 

By submitting this assignment I confirm that I understand and accept the terms of the Open Window Plagiarism Declaration. Please see openwindow.co.za/plagiarism for more information.

Students will only receive a pass or fail mark for each task, in order to pass the module all components need to be submitted on time and in the correct format as stipulated in the module brief.

tasks.title: Task 2: Profile Image, Link to Portfolio and Email Address
tasks.description:
PLEASE NOTE: no submissions  for this task will be accepted if they are not submitted via this Google Form

YOU DO NOT HAVE TO SUBMIT ANYTHING HERE ON CANVAS, JUST FILL IN THE FORM. IF YOU WANT IT TO SAY THAT YOU HAVE 'SUBMITTED', YOU MAY SUBMIT A SCREENSHOT OF THE EMAIL RESPONSE YOU GOT FROM THE FORM.

 

ASSESSMENT TASK 2

LEASE NOTE: no submissions  for this task will be accepted if they are not submitted via this Google Form

Have a look at some examples of the practical tasks, pay specific focus to slides 14 and onwards for examples of Task 3 components

Students should profile themselves using the following:

1. SINGLE IMAGE SHOWCASING WORK

You need to submit a single image (jpeg / PNG) that serves to represent your entire portfolio. This can be an image of your single best piece, a single image showcasing a number of pieces in a layout, or a gif looping a variety of up to three images (as long as it is 500px x 500px, even if it is a gif). However, the single image cannot be a portrait of yourself but must be an extract of your own portfolio. Here is a quick video tutorial to show you how to export and save there images for web from Photoshop, please follow these steps.

SUBMISSION REQUIREMENTS:

 500px X 500px - RGB, save for web

The image should be named: StudentName_Surname_Degree_Major

File size: under 10mb

 

2. Submit ONE LINK to a LIVE ONLINE PORTFOLIO/ ONE LINKTREE LINK that links to multiple platforms with your work. Based on your major subjects, the following platforms are recommended platforms for your online portfolios:

Please note, social media sites like Instagram or a Facebook page are not valid for the purposes of this professional online portfolio. Your link also needs to be a live, publicly accessible link (even if it is a live Google Slides link!). 

Based on your major subjects, the following platforms are recommended platforms for your online portfolios (submit a linkree link):

 

AA subjects:

3D: YouTube / Vimeo, Sketchfab (for 3D models) 

MD: YouTube / Vimeo

GD: YouTube / Vimeo, Git repository (for developers) and .itch page (for games), own site (optional)

 

FA subjects:

Film & TV: Vimeo or YouTube channels with showreels

Screen Acting: Vimeo or YouTube channels with showreels

Sound Design: Vimeo or YouTube channels with showreels

Production Design: Behance

Screenwriting: own website / substack

 

VC Subjects:

Photography, Illustration and Comm Design: Own website or Behance

 

CT Subjects:

User Experience Design: Own Website, Behance

Interactive Development: Github Repository, Own Website

Product Design: Own Website, Behance

 

3. SUBMIT AN OFFICIAL EMAIL ADDRESS FOR BUSINESS AND/OR PROFESSIONAL PURPOSES

Submit an official email address that potential clients and industry professionals may contact you.

Strong diversity with relevant subjects, showing a good understanding of client appeal and market relevance.
Adequate diversity but limited in terms of market appeal; some subjects may not fully resonate with clients.
Basic selection of subjects; lacks variety and relevance to market trends.
Minimal subject selection; lacks appeal and relevance; poorly aligned with market expectations.
No subject selection; fails to demonstrate understanding of commercial photography.
No submission

rubric.long_description: Students must choose a diverse range of subjects across different commercial genres (e.g., product, lifestyle, fashion, architecture) that reflect current market trends. Each subject should appeal to potential clients and showcase the student’s versatility and creativity.

ratings.long_description: Outstanding conceptual depth; themes are innovative and deeply resonate with the target audience with strong emotional impact.
Clear conceptualization and themes are relevant and connect well with the audience, evoking emotion.
Basic conceptual understanding; some themes present but lack depth or a strong connection to the audience.
Limited conceptualization and the themes are weak or poorly executed; minimal emotional engagement.
Little to no conceptual development; themes are absent or irrelevant to the audience.
No evidence of conceptualization; lacks narrative or emotional engagement.

rubric.long_description: Conceptualisation involves developing themes and narratives that enhance the storytelling aspect of the portfolio. Students should aim to evoke specific emotions or ideas in their images, showcasing their unique perspective and artistic voice throughout the selected genres.

ratings.long_description: In-depth research showcased, demonstrating a comprehensive understanding of conventions; and unique insights applied effectively.
Thorough research evident; demonstrates a good understanding of conventions and some innovative applications.
Basic research was conducted and the student demonstrated an understanding of some conventions but lacked depth.
Limited research; understanding of conventions is superficial and poorly applied.
Minimal or no research was conducted. The student fails to demonstrate an understanding of conventions.
No research or investigation is evident; lacks foundational knowledge.

rubric.long_description: Thorough research into each genre's technical and conceptual conventions is essential. Students should explore lighting, composition, and styling standards, applying their insights to enhance the originality and quality of their work in each genre.

ratings.long_description: High level of technical skill; lighting, composition, and post-production are executed flawlessly. Professional quality in all images.
Strong technical execution; minor issues in lighting or composition; overall professionalism in the images.
Adequate technical skills displayed but some noticeable issues in execution affecting professionalism
Basic technical execution; several issues in lighting or composition significantly affect image quality.
Significant technical flaws. There is a lack of basic skills evident in most images.
No technical skills demonstrated; images are unprofessional and poorly executed.
No submission

rubric.long_description: Technical proficiency is crucial for creating high-quality images that meet professional standards. Students should demonstrate skill in lighting control, composition, camera techniques, and post-production editing, ensuring consistency and precision across all images in their portfolio.

tasks.title: Task 1: My own choice clients
tasks.description:
Write proposals motivating your concepts for your Commercial portfolio of 20 images.

This project continues the development of your professional commercial portfolio, expanding on the work completed in Semester 1. The aim is to grow your portfolio from 40 to 60 high quality commercial images, showcasing your ability to work across a wider range of commercial genres. The focus is on refining your technical execution, strengthening your stylistic voice, and responding more directly to real-world commercial demands.

You are expected to add 20 new images in this first part of Semester 2, working toward your final goal of a comprehensive and diverse commercial body of work. The final portfolio should reflect both creative versatility and professional consistency across all selected genres.

Task Requirements

  • Produce 20 new, professionally executed images in Semester 2 (Part 1).

  • Expand your portfolio to include at least 5 commercial genres in total by the end of the semester.

  • Build on your original proposal and refine your creative direction as needed.

  • Present a cohesive, client-oriented body of work that demonstrates technical and conceptual growth.

  • Two product shoots that include motion-based content—preferably video—to demonstrate your ability to work across media and produce content suited to digital platforms

1. Selecting Your Genres

  • You must work across a minimum of five distinct commercial genres. These may include (but are not limited to):
  • Consider the relevance of each genre in the current industry and how it connects to your emerging identity as a commercial photographer. Select genres that allow you to demonstrate range while still developing a recognisable visual style.

2. Target Clients and Objectives

For each genre, identify a hypothetical or real client (brand, company, publication, or service) and outline the intended purpose of the images. This might include:

  • Brand campaigns

  • Social media content

  • Website visuals

  • Promotional material

  • Editorial spreads

Your work should reflect a clear understanding of client needs and the intended commercial platform.

3. Influential Photographers and Artists

You are required to research two influential photographers and/ or Artists per genre. 

  • Discuss what makes their work successful within the genre.

  • Explain how their style, use of lighting, composition, or branding informs your creative direction.

  • Reflect critically on how your work builds on or diverges from these references.

4. Visual Mood Board

Update or refine your mood boards to guide your Semester 2 production. Each genre should include:

  • Reference images that inform your visual language.

  • Lighting diagrams or test images that reflect your intended look and feel. Mention the equipment or techniques you intend to use to achieve your desired results.

  • Notes on composition, styling, and tone.

  • Annotations showing how your vision and interpretation come through.

  • Discuss any technical challenges you foresee in executing the shoots (e.g., lighting setups, location constraints) and how you plan to overcome them.

Your mood boards should act as a visual blueprint for the shoots to follow and should remain consistent with your evolving personal brand.

5. Presentation

  • Your proposal should be professional, cohesive, and visually engaging.
  • Submit the document in PDF format for review.

Practical Approach

You are expected to:

  • Plan, shoot, and post-produce your images to a professional industry standard.

  • Use appropriate lighting, styling, and retouching techniques relevant to your chosen genres.

  • Work with models, stylists, and/or clients (where appropriate) to simulate real-world production environments.

  • Show experimentation and risk-taking where relevant, while maintaining commercial viability.

Keep process documentation (e.g. lighting setups, test shoots, production notes) to support your workflow and include this in your final submission.

raw_canvas_data.name: Task 1: My own choice clients

ratings.long_description: Demonstrates a highly organized and meticulous approach with thorough research and detailed planning. The process is innovative, showing a deep understanding of commercial photography.
Well-structured process with clear evidence of research and planning. The approach is solid, with some innovative elements.
Adequately structured process with basic research and planning. The approach is functional but lacks innovation.
Somewhat disorganized process with limited research and planning. Lacks depth and originality.
Poorly organized process with minimal research or planning. Lacks clarity and coherence.
Disorganized process with no clear structure, research, or planning. Does not meet task requirements.
No submission

rubric.long_description: This criterion evaluates the student's approach to developing their commercial portfolio. It includes the level of organization, research, planning, and the ability to effectively manage the entire process from concept to execution. A strong process demonstrates a clear structure, innovation, and a thorough understanding of the task at hand.

ratings.long_description: Exceptional conceptual development with original, well-thought-out ideas. The concepts are innovative and clearly articulated.
Strong conceptual development with creative and relevant ideas. The concepts are well-developed and persuasive.
Solid conceptual development with appropriate but less innovative ideas. Some concepts are underdeveloped.
Basic conceptual development with functional but shallow ideas. Lacks depth and originality.
Weak conceptual development with underdeveloped or inappropriate ideas. Lacks clarity.
Very poor conceptual development with little to no relevant ideas. Concepts are nonexistent or completely inappropriate.

rubric.long_description: This criterion assesses the originality, creativity, and clarity of the concepts presented in the proposal. It considers how well the student has developed and articulated their ideas, how relevant and innovative the concepts are, and the depth of thought behind each idea. Strong conceptual development should show a clear connection between the concept and the intended commercial application.

ratings.long_description: Outstanding presentation that is highly professional, visually compelling, and well-organized. Visual references strongly support the concepts.
Strong presentation that is professional and well-organized. Visual references effectively support the concepts.
Solid presentation that is functional and clear. Visual references support the concepts, though presentation lacks polish.
Basic presentation that is somewhat disorganized and lacks polish. Visual references are minimal and less effective.
Weak presentation that is poorly organized and lacks clarity. Visual references are insufficient.
Very poor presentation that is disorganized and unprofessional. Visual references are missing or entirely ineffective.

rubric.long_description: This criterion focuses on the overall quality and professionalism of the proposal presentation. It evaluates how well the proposal is organized, the visual appeal, and the effectiveness of visual references such as mood boards, inspiration images, and sample photographs in supporting the concepts. A strong presentation is both visually compelling and clearly communicated, making the proposal easy to understand and persuasive.

  • Plan, shoot, and post-produce your images to a professional industry standard.

  • Use appropriate lighting, styling, and retouching techniques relevant to your chosen genres.

  • Work with models, stylists, and/or clients (where appropriate) to simulate real-world production environments.

  • Show experimentation and risk-taking where relevant, while maintaining commercial viability.

Keep process documentation (e.g. lighting setups, test shoots, production notes) to support your workflow and include this in your final submission.

tasks.title: Task 2.1: Commercial Portfolio development
tasks.description:
This project aims to develop your ability to create a professional, client-focused commercial photography portfolio that demonstrates both technical expertise and conceptual depth. You will build a diverse body of work across multiple commercial genres, refining your personal style while meeting real-world industry standards. Through research, planning, and execution, this project will prepare you for professional photographic practice by fostering critical thinking, creative problem-solving, and effective communication.

Project Overview

As part of your Photography 300 course, you are required to build a comprehensive commercial portfolio comprising 60 final images to be submitted at the end of Semester 2.

Your portfolio must include:

  • A minimum of five distinct commercial genres

  • At least 10 final images per genre

  • A broad range of subjects that appeal to professional clients and reflect current industry trends

  • Two product shoots that include motion-based content, preferably video, to demonstrate your ability to work across media and produce content suited to digital platforms

Project Tasks

1. Selecting Commercial Subjects
Choose commercial subjects that reflect a diverse range of genres and appeal to potential clients. Your choices should be relevant to current industry trends and allow for creative and technical exploration.

2. Conducting an Intensive Investigation
Engage in in-depth research of your chosen commercial subjects. Explore their visual and conceptual nuances thoroughly, bringing your unique perspective through both technical mastery and conceptual insight. This will help you build expertise and a personal voice within each genre.

3. Creating Creative Briefs
Develop at least ten detailed Creative Briefs, each tailored to guide your photographic work for specific genres or clients. These briefs will motivate your concepts and clarify your approach, preparing you for professional industry standards. Ensure that your briefs employ professional language and formatting, reflecting insights from industry talks and mimicking communication with production houses and agencies.

Technical and Conceptual Considerations

Apply the Rule of Threes as a critical tool for evaluating and producing your images. This framework will assist with peer and self-assessment throughout your shoots:

1. Technical Fundamentals:

    • Lighting: key light, fill light, backlight
    • Camera settings: aperture, shutter speed, ISO
    • Lens choice: wide, standard, long focal lengths

2. Composition Techniques:

    • Use of leading lines, foreground, middle ground, and background
    • Eye trace, rule of thirds, and visual balance

3. Conceptual/Theoretical Framework:

    • Locality and subject relevance
    • Meaningful storytelling and brand alignment

Presentation and Submission

  • Upload all five edited images to your Student Work folder, naming files as follows: PH300_Name Surname_S2_Task_2025
  • Present your progress images during practical classes through a Google Slides presentation, including a link to your developing Treatments.
  • Your Portfolio development will be reviewed and discussed during these sessions

Learning Outcomes

By completing this project, you will:

  • Refine your technical skills and deepen your understanding of photographic fundamentals.
  • Develop the ability to plan, conceptualise, and execute commercial photography projects aligned with client briefs.
  • Gain experience in professional communication through well-structured creative briefs.
  • Build a versatile, well-researched commercial portfolio that demonstrates both technical proficiency and conceptual maturity.

tasks.title: Task 3 Part 1: Proposal for your Artist Book
tasks.description:
Introduction
As part of your final-year submission, you are required to conceptualise, design, and produce a professionally printed Artist’s Book. Artist’s books are considered artworks in their own right, bringing together photography, text, design, and materiality to reflect a personal or conceptual narrative.

To prepare for this project, you will visit the Jack Ginsberg Centre for Book Arts in Week 1. The Centre houses one of the world’s most extensive collections of artists’ books and serves as an inspiration for thinking beyond conventional book formats. During the visit, pay attention to the experimental use of materials, sequencing, binding, and visual storytelling strategies.

Part 1: Write a brief proposal for your Artist’s book Rationale

  • Create a visual and creative document that outlines your proposed theme, topic, and conceptual direction for your Artist’s Book.
  • This proposal should integrate visual elements (such as mood boards, sketches, test images, or layout ideas) and written reflections.
  • Your creative proposal must also include a reference to one seminal text that supports or contextualises your chosen theme.

Think of this document as a working sketchbook or presentation that visually communicates your intent, mood, and research direction.

Please upload this task as a Google Doc (no PDF's) or Google Slides and rename your file PHO 300_Name Surname_Task number (S2)_2025.

Strong concept, compelling rationale, clear connection to the chosen topic, and good understanding of the artistic direction.
Adequately explained concept, lacks depth or originality, clear rationale but needs more detailed articulation of the artistic direction.
The basic concept is somewhat clear but lacks originality or depth, the rationale is vague or insufficiently developed.
Struggles to present a coherent concept, unclear or underdeveloped rationale, disconnected from the artistic direction.
Fails to present a clear concept, little to no rationale, incoherent or absent idea.

The student effectively connects their work to existing practices or societal themes, showing deep insight and understanding.

Adequate research, some level of contextualization, present connection to broader frameworks but somewhat superficial or underdeveloped.
Limited research, basic or minimal connections to broader frameworks, understanding of context is present but not well-articulated.
The proposal struggles to present a coherent concept. The rationale is unclear, underdeveloped, or disconnected from the artistic direction.
The proposal fails to present a clear concept, with little to no rationale provided. The idea is either incoherent or absent.

rubric.long_description: Evaluates the depth of research and how well the student contextualizes their project within broader artistic, cultural, or historical frameworks. This includes the ability to connect their work to existing art practices or relevant societal themes.

ratings.long_description: The supporting visuals are exceptional, with a highly relevant and visually compelling selection that enhances the proposal. The images are clearly connected to the concept and demonstrate a strong artistic vision.
The supporting visuals are strong and effectively enhance the proposal. The images are relevant and well-chosen, showing a good connection to the concept and artistic vision.
The supporting visuals are adequate and support the proposal, but they may lack impact or clear connection to the concept. The artistic vision is present but could be stronger.
The supporting visuals are basic and offer some support to the proposal, but they may be poorly chosen or disconnected from the concept. The artistic vision is not well-represented.
The supporting visuals are weak, with minimal relevance or connection to the concept. The images fail to enhance the proposal or convey the artistic vision effectively.
The supporting visuals are absent or entirely irrelevant, offering no support to the proposal or connection to the concept.

rubric.long_description: Evaluates the effectiveness of the supporting visuals and seminal text in reinforcing the proposed concept. This includes the relevance of mood boards, inspiration images, and the quality of the cited text.

tasks.title: Task 4: Experimental portrait video
tasks.description:
Create an experimental moving portrait.

This project introduces students to experimental moving image as preparation for a later Fashion Film assignment. Working within creative constraints, you’ll conceptualise and produce a 30–60 second moving portrait that captures emotion, gesture, and presence, using limited camera angles and supported by sound design and post-production techniques.

You will collaborate with Screen Acting 300 students to bring your portrait to life. This is also an opportunity to network with actors for future work, such as headshots and fashion photography projects.

Workshop Collaboration with Screen Acting
Briefing: Tuesday, 22 July at 13:00

Workshop Introduction

You will be guided in a hands-on workshop led by Christo Niemandt (Open Window’s Content Creator).
The session will cover:

  • Basic camera settings for moving portraits

  • Understanding and planning an A-roll and B-roll shot list

  • Visual narrative and storyboarding under constraints

Inspiration & Reference Works

We will explore the following works to inspire your approach to visual storytelling, restriction, and experimental form:

  • “Evil Instinct” by Nadav Kander
    A series of emotionally intense moving portraits, shot in slow motion, explores subtle human gestures and inner psychological tension.

  • “The Perfect Human” by Jørgen Leth
    A minimalist 1967 short film that dissects human behaviour and rituals through poetic, detached narration and controlled framing.

  • “The Five Obstructions” by Lars von Trier
    A documentary in which director Jørgen Leth is challenged to remake “The Perfect Human” five times, each with new creative constraints, revealing how limitation fuels innovation.

  • “Furious Portraits” by Dmitri Pryahin
    A raw and expressive video series capturing intense emotional states through close-up performance, lighting, and sound, creating a visceral viewer experience.

The Task: Create an Experimental Moving Portrait

Requirements:

    • Length: 30–60 seconds

    • Camera setup: 1 camera, 2 static tripod angles (A-roll and B-roll only)

    • Framing: Focus on facial expressions, gesture, and body language

    • Collaboration: Select a subject (actor) from the Screen Acting 300 group

    • Sound: Include ambient sounds, music, or voice elements to enhance mood

    • Post-production: Add title plates, transitions, and motion effects to support the narrative

Themes

Themes will be provided in class to inspire narrative and mood. Choose one and interpret it creatively but sensitively in your visual direction.

Technical Specifications

  • Export as: .mp4

  • Codec: H.264

  • Resolution: Full HD 1080p

  • Submission format: Upload to Canvas and/or Drive folder (to be shared)

Collaboration Details

  • Briefing session: Tuesday, 22 July at 13:00

  • You will be paired with Screen Acting 300 students

Use this opportunity to connect and discuss mutual needs, from headshots to casting actors for fashion films and beyond

Create an experimental moving portrait.

This project introduces students to experimental moving image as preparation for a later Fashion Film assignment. Working within creative constraints, you’ll conceptualise and produce a 30–60 second moving portrait that captures emotion, gesture, and presence, using limited camera angles and supported by sound design and post-production techniques.

You will collaborate with Screen Acting 300 students to bring your portrait to life. This is also an opportunity to network with actors for future work, such as headshots and fashion photography projects.

Workshop Collaboration with Screen Acting
Briefing: Tuesday, 22 July at 13:00

Workshop Introduction

You will be guided in a hands-on workshop led by Christo Niemandt (Open Window’s Content Creator).
The session will cover:

  • Basic camera settings for moving portraits

  • Understanding and planning an A-roll and B-roll shot list

  • Visual narrative and storyboarding under constraints

Inspiration & Reference Works

We will explore the following works to inspire your approach to visual storytelling, restriction, and experimental form:

  • “Evil Instinct” by Nadav Kander
    A series of emotionally intense moving portraits, shot in slow motion, explores subtle human gestures and inner psychological tension.

  • “The Perfect Human” by Jørgen Leth
    A minimalist 1967 short film that dissects human behaviour and rituals through poetic, detached narration and controlled framing.

  • “The Five Obstructions” by Lars von Trier
    A documentary in which director Jørgen Leth is challenged to remake “The Perfect Human” five times, each with new creative constraints, revealing how limitation fuels innovation.

  • “Furious Portraits” by Dmitri Pryahin
    A raw and expressive video series capturing intense emotional states through close-up performance, lighting, and sound, creating a visceral viewer experience.

The Task: Create an Experimental Moving Portrait

Requirements:

    • Length: 30–60 seconds

    • Camera setup: 1 camera, 2 static tripod angles (A-roll and B-roll only)

    • Framing: Focus on facial expressions, gesture, and body language

    • Collaboration: Select a subject (actor) from the Screen Acting 300 group

    • Sound: Include ambient sounds, music, or voice elements to enhance mood

    • Post-production: Add title plates, transitions, and motion effects to support the narrative

Themes

Themes will be provided in class to inspire narrative and mood. Choose one and interpret it creatively but sensitively in your visual direction.

Technical Specifications

  • Export as: .mp4

  • Codec: H.264

  • Resolution: Full HD 1080p

  • Submission format: Upload to Canvas and/or Drive folder (to be shared)

Collaboration Details

  • Briefing session: Tuesday, 22 July at 13:00

  • You will be paired with Screen Acting 300 students

Use this opportunity to connect and discuss mutual needs, from headshots to casting actors for fashion films and beyond

tasks.title: Task 3 Part 2: Rationale
tasks.description:
Part 2: Write the rationale for your Artist’s book

Your rationale should be a more academic document (800–1000 words) that critically articulates the conceptual framework, photographic approach, and narrative intent behind your book. This should be supported by:

  • 3–5 cited academic or critical texts

  • Visual documentation of your test shoots, contact sheets, or visual research

  • A discussion of layout, materiality, and the intended reader experience

The rationale will be included in your final printed book in the form of a Preface and is essential in demonstrating both conceptual depth and technical reflection.

tasks.title: Task 2.3: Commercial Portfolio development
tasks.description:
This project aims to develop your ability to create a professional, client-focused commercial photography portfolio that demonstrates both technical expertise and conceptual depth. You will build a diverse body of work across multiple commercial genres, refining your personal style while meeting real-world industry standards. Through research, planning, and execution, this project will prepare you for professional photographic practice by fostering critical thinking, creative problem-solving, and effective communication.

Project Overview

As part of your Photography 300 course, you are required to build a comprehensive commercial portfolio comprising 60 final images to be submitted at the end of Semester 2.

Your portfolio must include:

  • A minimum of five distinct commercial genres

  • At least 10 final images per genre

  • A broad range of subjects that appeal to professional clients and reflect current industry trends

  • Two product shoots that include motion-based content, preferably video, to demonstrate your ability to work across media and produce content suited to digital platforms

Project Tasks

1. Selecting Commercial Subjects
Choose commercial subjects that reflect a diverse range of genres and appeal to potential clients. Your choices should be relevant to current industry trends and allow for creative and technical exploration.

2. Conducting an Intensive Investigation
Engage in in-depth research of your chosen commercial subjects. Explore their visual and conceptual nuances thoroughly, bringing your unique perspective through both technical mastery and conceptual insight. This will help you build expertise and a personal voice within each genre.

3. Creating Creative Briefs
Develop at least ten detailed Creative Briefs, each tailored to guide your photographic work for specific genres or clients. These briefs will motivate your concepts and clarify your approach, preparing you for professional industry standards. Ensure that your briefs employ professional language and formatting, reflecting insights from industry talks and mimicking communication with production houses and agencies.

Technical and Conceptual Considerations

Apply the Rule of Threes as a critical tool for evaluating and producing your images. This framework will assist with peer and self-assessment throughout your shoots:

1. Technical Fundamentals:

    • Lighting: key light, fill light, backlight
    • Camera settings: aperture, shutter speed, ISO
    • Lens choice: wide, standard, long focal lengths

2. Composition Techniques:

    • Use of leading lines, foreground, middle ground, and background
    • Eye trace, rule of thirds, and visual balance

3. Conceptual/Theoretical Framework:

    • Locality and subject relevance
    • Meaningful storytelling and brand alignment

Presentation and Submission

  • Upload all five edited images to your Student Work folder, naming files as follows: PH300_Name Surname_S2_Task_2025
  • Present your progress images during practical classes through a Google Slides presentation, including a link to your developing Treatments.
  • Your Portfolio development will be reviewed and discussed during these sessions

Learning Outcomes

By completing this project, you will:

  • Refine your technical skills and deepen your understanding of photographic fundamentals.
  • Develop the ability to plan, conceptualise, and execute commercial photography projects aligned with client briefs.
  • Gain experience in professional communication through well-structured creative briefs.
  • Build a versatile, well-researched commercial portfolio that demonstrates both technical proficiency and conceptual maturity.

tasks.title: How to upload your work to Google Drive
tasks.description:
PHOTOGRAPHY 300 | SEMESTER 1

GOOGLE DRIVE UPLOADS AND TASK SUBMISSIONS 

Lecturer: Jorina Botha

Contact: jorina@openwindow.co.za

 

Follow these steps when uploading your work to Google Drive:

Instructions:

  • Open the Google Drive link found here.

You will find 3x folders: 

    1. Student Work
    2. Final Semester Presentations
    3. Best Work
    4. Group Work

Open the Student Work folder and create a folder inside using your Name Surname and Student number.

Subdivide the folder into Semester 1 and Semester 2. Please NO SUBFOLDERS in any of the other folders unless specified. 

You will be using this folder to upload your work submitted onto Canvas.  Name your files as Follows: PH300_Name Surname_S1_Task_2025

 

At the end of each Semester, you need to upload your work as follows:

  • In the Final Semester Presentation folder, you will be uploading your presentation for your Semester Evaluation. Presentations must be named as follows:  PH300_Name Surname_Presentation S1_2024. (S1) stands for Semester 1 replace it with (S2) in Semester 2
  • Best work folder. At the end of each semester, upload your best work to the appropriate semester folder. This folder is reserved for your top-quality submissions. The work that showcases your skills and represents your finest achievements. No subfolders are allowed here, all files should be uploaded directly to keep things streamlined and easy to navigate. Name your images as follows: PH300_Name Surname_Task number (S1)_2024 (S1) stands for Semester 1 replace it with (S2) in Semester 2
  • The Group Work folder will be discussed in class. A designated group leader must always be responsible for uploading the group’s work to the appropriate folder. Ensure that the work is clearly labelled and organized according to the guidelines provided during class discussions.

tasks.title: Mobile App - Project Pitch
tasks.description:
Project Pitch

Theme 3 - Mobile App - Project Pitch
Formative Assessment

Your assigned inspiration cards will enforce the application theme, feature requirements and the functionality that you will need to implement for your mobile application.

To map out your vision for your mobile app before diving into code, you will be required to create a project pitch document. It’s where you’ll define what you’re building, who it’s for, why it matters, and how you plan to pull it off using React Native and Firebase. The goal isn’t just to “get an idea approved” but to sharpen your thinking and set yourself up for a successful build.

Refer to the brief for more information.

 

HAND-IN

SUBMISSION DEADLINE

21 July 2025 at 23:59 (Week 3)

Format - PDF

 

LATE SUBMISSION
Late submissions are accepted for a maximum of 48 hours after the allocated deadline given in your brief.  Any work submitted during these 48 hours will be evaluated, but will only be awarded a maximum of 50% as a late-submission penalty. After 48 hours, 0% will be awarded. OW takes a zero-tolerance stance on work submitted later than 48 hours after the deadline.
PLAGIARISM DECLARATION
By submitting this assignment, I confirm that I understand and accept the terms of the Open Window Plagiarism Declaration. Please see openwindow.co.za/plagiarism for more information.

PROGRESS FEEDBACK

Theme 3 - Mobile App - Progress Milestone & Code Review
Formative Assessment

Throughout the theme, we'll be conducting progress feedback and code reviews to help track your development and ensure you're on the right path to complete the project. Each of you will have individual check-ins for grading and feedback.
You will randomly be selected to showcase your progress and have a code review in one of these weeks. Therefore, you will need to ensure that you properly plan and manage the sprints of your projects to make continuous progress and to be ready for your stand-up meeting in either one of these weeks. 

Both the milestones and code reviews are designed not just to assess your work but also to guide your learning. If you do not continuously work on this project, it can negatively impact your marks.

Refer to the brief and rubric below for more information.

tasks.title: Final Mobile App Demonstration
tasks.description:
MOBILE APP DEMO

Theme 3 - Final Demonstration Video of Mobile Application
Summative Assessment

Instead of doing a live presentation, you will be required to submit a demonstration video of your mobile application.

    • Your video should be 10 minutes to explain and demonstrate your project.
    • In the first 1-2 minutes of your video, explain the 3 inspiration cards that you received, explain the application that you decided to build based on these cards, and how you approached the project implementation.
    • While demonstrating your app, try and refer to how you implemented the functionality using appropriate terminology.
    • You are required to demonstrate your application live in your video.
    • This is not a presentation, but approach it with the same professionalism.
    • Have your application running before the demonstration starts.
    • Make sure that your GitHub Repository has all the latest commits on the main branch, with all the appropriate documentation, because this will be reviewed alongside your video demonstration.
    • The demonstration video should be included in your documentation (readme).

Refer to the brief for more information.

tasks.title: Final Mobile Application
tasks.description:
FINAL MOBILE APP

Theme 3 - Final GitHub Repository for Mobile Application
Summative Assessment

This is the final goal of the theme. This term, you’ll be challenged to develop a mobile application… but with a creative twist. Instead of being handed a fixed brief, you’ll draw Inspiration Cards that combine unexpected themes, technologies, and user scenarios. These cards will guide your project’s direction, encouraging you to think beyond conventional app ideas and embrace the kind of inventive problem-solving used in real-world product teams. 

This cross-platform mobile app will be written as a React Native project and interface with Google Firebase as a Backend Service. These technologies are ideal to build mobile apps for the rapid implementation benefits they provide. This mobile app will need to be compatible for deployment on both Android & iOS.

You are required to utilise Git and GitHub to implement version control into your projects. Regular pushes and merges are expected, with clear branching strategies to avoid conflicts. Your assessors will assess the frequency, consistency and quality of your commits over the term. Your GitHub repository will be the final hand-in format for your theme project. 

Make sure that your lecturer can access your codebase and that you have included the appropriate project documentation (with all of the required information). Your repository should contain all of the latest commits in the main branch.

Refer to the brief for more information.

 

HAND-IN

SUBMISSION DEADLINE

22 August 2025 at 23:59 (Week 7 - extended)

Format - GitHub Repository Link

 

LATE SUBMISSION
Late submissions are accepted for a maximum of 48 hours after the allocated deadline given in your brief.  Any work submitted during these 48 hours will be evaluated, but will only be awarded a maximum of 50% as a late-submission penalty. After 48 hours, 0% will be awarded. OW takes a zero-tolerance stance on work submitted later than 48 hours after the deadline.
PLAGIARISM DECLARATION

tasks.title: AI-Driven App - Project Pitch
tasks.description:
Project Pitch

Theme 4 - AI-Driven App - Project Pitch
Formative Assessment

There are very few limitations with this project, but that means the responsibility will be on you for the decisions you make. These decisions will be guided through your research, planning and the class activities you complete each week.

In this first phase of the project, you will be spending time researching various problems and identifying what application you would like to build to solve this problem. This will include planning the type of AI technologies and the frameworks, as well as any technical planning, such as the user-flow and the scope of the project.

As part of the user interface implementation, you will also be required to create a brand identity and aesthetic for the frontend of you app. This includes logos, copy, appropriate imagery and icons, along with standard UI styling. As part of your research and planning, you will be required to create moodboards, wireframes and style guides.

All of this planning & research needs to be compiled into a project proposal.

Refer to the brief for more information.

 

HAND-IN

SUBMISSION DEADLINE

22 September 2025 at 23:59 (Week 10)

Format - PDF

Qualifier - This assignment acts as a qualifier for your progress milestone assessment. If you do not submit this document, you will still receive feedback during the progress review, but you will receive 0%.

 

LATE SUBMISSION
Late submissions are accepted for a maximum of 48 hours after the allocated deadline given in your brief.  Any work submitted during these 48 hours will be evaluated, but will only be awarded a maximum of 50% as a late-submission penalty. After 48 hours, 0% will be awarded. OW takes a zero-tolerance stance on work submitted later than 48 hours after the deadline.
